critique: This document establishes the position of Federal Coordinator of Transportation and appoints Joseph B. Eastman to the role. It also outlines the powers and duties of the Coordinator, including the ability to appoint assistants and agents. The document appears to expand executive power by granting the President the authority to appoint the Coordinator and approve their appointments. It also seems to favor federal control by creating a federal position to oversee interstate railroad transportation. The document does not seem to directly address immigration, national security, economic regulation, or social inclusion. Therefore, those axes will be scored as neutral. The ideological tilt is difficult to assess, but given the context of the New Deal era, it is likely moderately liberal due to the increased government intervention in the economy.
